docs.lead_paragraph: ST. VINCENT'S Medical Center in Bridgeport, the PHP Healthcare Corporation of Reston, Va., and hundreds of Fairfield County health professionals have joined forces in a new company called Connecticut Health Enterprise. At a time when the rules of the health-care system are increasingly set by cost-conscious insurance companies, officials of the new partnership say their venture will return authority to doctors. What makes Connecticut Health Enterprise different, say its founders, is the participation of PHP Healthcare, with its computer system and health-care management program.

headline.main: Doctors at Work To Regain Some Power

docs.lead_paragraph: RAYMOND MAKORI, 19, has his eye on a car, a sporty used Mitsubishi Starion. So at 3 P.M. five times a week -- more often, if he can get the overtime -- he takes a bus from his home here to the gatehouse at the sprawling Panasonic headquarters in Secaucus to begin an eight-hour shift as a security guard. There would be nothing unusual about Raymond's $6-an-hour job, or his dream of new wheels, if it were not for the way he plans to use them. "I need a car so I can get a second job on weekends," he said the other day. "I have to pay part of the household bills and the rent." And he has to pay nearly $3,000 a year for tuition (and help pay it for his younger brother and sisters) at St. Aloysius High School in Jersey City, where he will be a senior in the fall.
